comments.comment: Hopefully this will clear things up:   At the beginning of the year, they raised money by selling 1/3 of the equity in the company for $500 and also raised $250 through a debt issue. Cash balance: $750 = 500 + 250 They then spent $300 to buy the first stand and $200 on inventory (this is your cost of goods sold, or COGS). Cash balance: $250 = 750 - 300 - 200 At the end of year 1, we see they sold $800 of lemonade, and paid $530 in labor costs (remember, we already bought the inventory, and depreciation is a "non-cash" charge - we're accounting for having to replace the lemonade stand every 5 years). Cash balance: $520 = 250 + 800 - 530 Finally, they paid $25 in interest, leaving them with negative EBT (earnings before tax) of $15 and therefore had a tax credit of $5 (this was sort of skipped over): Cash balance: $500 = 520 - 25 + 5  Note this matches the ending cash balance (bottom line) in the cash flow statement at 8:15. With that, we have enough to spend $300 on a second lemonade stand with money to spare.

comments.comment: It comes ftom cash generated from operating activities, i.e. selling lemonaid. At the end of Year 1 you have $800 in revenue + $250 residual cash left after buying the 1st stand and inventories - $530 labour costs - $25 debt + $5 tax compensation. That brings you to $500 neccessary to start up another lemonaid stand. Or you can do it another way: go to the Cash Flow Statement (@ 08:19) and see step by step how you come to $500 at the end of Year 1.

comments.comment: Great explanation.  Some typos though, to my understanding. At 7:43, the chart shows $850 in first year instead of $800.  Also, I don't think year 2,3,4 Per Share should be negative.   Also, Growth should be calculated differently from Negative to Positive: from year 1 ($10) to year 2 +$90, there is positive growth of $100 which yield 1000% Growth (positive).

comments.comment: Some people noticed a flaw in the growth assumptions like: "How did he pay for another stand, and what about, getting more inventory for the next stand..." at 6:48  My way of getting around that, is just by making the following assumption: The owner is going to work at the first Stand, then the "labor" cost, is actually reinvested in the company.  As First Assumptions said: $300 for a Stand, $200 for a year of Inventory for 1 stand [Cogs price goes up each year].  Every year inventory per stand is already paid at the "Less: COGS" My money to reinvest comes from 1 Stand as Labor costs $530  With my $530, i can buy Another Stand and Enough inventory for the new stand (Remember that the first stand already paid its inventory at the end of the year)  From now on, lets continue with the "Income Statement: The Next Four Year" My Revenue in year 2 is $1764 Less: COGS (420) [210 per stand, 2 stands] Less: Depreciation (120)  Less: Labor (530) [Thats someone else i employed] Less: Labor (530) [That me working at first stand] ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- EBIT: $184 Less: Interest (25) Less: Taxes (65) [Assuming 35% of EBIT] ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Net Income: $81  If we continue reinvesting our $530 of our labor, at fifth year, we shall have enough cash to buy 3 stands and continue our growth xD.   At End of fourth year, we shall have a net income of $608 That, added to the net income of third year of $286 and the secont year $81.  Were sitting at $975 + $250 (initial cash) = $1225 That means: More then enough to sustein our growth (For now xD)

comments.comment: Small correction incase others noticed it as well. Overall, great content.   In the cash flow statement (at 8:19) under cash flow from operation, Year 1 would also show investment in Inventory of $200. That seems to be a miss. You started with $0 in cash, added $750 through debt & equity, invested $300 in capex and $200 in inventory. At the end of the year, cash flow from operations would be ($150). And ending cash would be $300. At year 2 start, they will need further cash injection to meet growth target.
